captions.text:
Wireless charging seems so great, I plug this
thingy in and then set this other thingy on

it… BAM power! But how the heck does electricity
get from the wall into my phone?

Hello everyone! Trace here for DNews, thanks
for stopping by! You're probably watching

this show via a device that has a battery.
Laptops, mobile phones, toothbrushes, though…

not this new watch everyone's talking about
for some reason… All these things need charging

and for the moment we're still using cords
and plugs for this… Inductive charging isn't

new, it's been used since the early 1990s
in electric toothbrushes, and for surgically

implanted devices like artificial hearts.
You've even heard of this in pop culture!

In the late 1800s, Tesla was allegedly able
to power light bulbs with no wires, and claimed

to be able to transmit power from one location
to another with no wires…

To make it work relies on simple physics.
If you ever wrapped a coil of wire around

a nail and attached a battery, then you know
the electricity in the battery runs through

the wire creating an electromagnetic field,
or flux. Do it at home, it's fun and you can
use it to pick up paperclips or whatever.

With that same principle, a coil of wire…
magnet… battery… you can make it go the

other way too. Spin a magnet in the coil and
you'll GENERATE electricity by taking that

magnetic flux and moving it through that coil
to create electricity.

The battery creates a stable electromagnet
because it's direct current, it's going one

way. The power from your walls is alternating
current, changes direction 60 times a second

-- or cycles at 60 hertz -- so the electrons
are moving back and forth -- remember that
because that's the key to the charging.

Wireless inductive charging gets its name
from that magnetic field interaction, called

induction. Inside of the charging pad, and
the inductive charging device are tiny coils

of wire. The pad, being plugged into the wall,
is fully powered -- and the power is cycling.

When the other coils come within a short distance
their flux will interact with the flux in

the device, move the electrons around and
charge the battery.

Chances are, the number of cycles per second
isn't going to be 60 hertz, but like, 5 or

10, so it doesn't mess up other things in
your house. Your WiFi network cycles at 2.4

gigahertz or 2.4 billion cycles per second,
so it's DEFINITELY not going to mess THAT

up, but with all the radio waves flying around,
you can't be too careful.

If it's that easy, you'd think it would be
everywhere, but the problem is efficiency.

You waste a lot of power filling up two coils
and letting them talk to each other. It's
SO much better to just plug right in.

The future of wireless charging is unclear.
It seems like a great idea, but it's still

going to be a short-distance system for a
while. In 2006, MIT found if you match the

frequencies of the devices, you can make the
power go a few METERS -- so if you were in

your living room, and a charger was there
-- your phone would charge right in your pocket…

They're working on marketing the technology
now, but it's still not everywhere…
Mr. Tesla, we're getting there, man.

Speaking of awesome innovations - how about
ones that make flying a little less suckier?

That happens to be the focus of discussion
on THIS episode of Anyhoo, hosted by my friend
Catie Wayne. Check it out!

Back to wireless charging - what would you
want to power wirelessly? I'd love to beam

power to my TV! Then I could put it anywhere!
Down with cables! Leave your comments down
below, Please subscribe and thanks for watching!

comments.author: Florin Chirica

comments.text:
I'm sorry to be the bringer of bad news, or "mister know it all", but, I 
just wanted to point out that the power running through your walls is DC 
(NOT AC)! while the power running through the power-lines is AC, since AC 
is great for long distance packaging of high-voltages using power-stations, 
containing "Transformers". If the power-lines were DC, you'd need a 
power-station every so many blocks.
Just prior to getting to it's destination (for example, your house), the AC 
is converted to DC, using a "Rectifier" and stepped down to 120 volts (240 
volts in Europe), which is what is running through the wires in our walls 
and also what we receive from our sockets, to power our electrical 
appliances.
Thanks!﻿

comments.author: Shivam Patel

comments.text:
Matching resonant frequencies wasn't discovered in 2006 (that's pretty 
basic EE)... That MIT teams advancement was deciding to choose a frequency 
that gave them about a 2m distance in the near field. They also proved that 
by adjusting the resonant frequencies, the near field size can be changed. 
Also, the future is wireless power transmission. As an Electrical & 
Computer Engineering undergrad I made a wireless charging system for cell 
phones (not surface to surface induction mat style, but free space). This 
is getting easier and easier to do.﻿

induce (hence the term, inductive charging) the flow of current, or 
electricity in a nearby coil, thus charging your phone wirelessly.

comments.author: Kris S

comments.text:
+owen west
 I mentioned in another post that wireless charging for cars right now is 
simply done by parking over a specialized mat or pad in one's garage and 
they've achieved efficiencies very close to traditional wired connection 
(just above 90%) and experimental systems using a cable embedding in the 
road to wireless run electric buses while driving are underway. Yes, the 
cost of the vehicles are higher when compared to traditional gas powered 
ones, but that will really only be true until the technology becomes more 
common place, plus most governments offer subsidies or tax write-offs on 
hybrid and electric cars to offset some of the difference (the price 
difference.for hybrids has decreased since their introduction). Plus with 
Tesla Motors effectively putting the technology for the electric car into 
the public domain, within a few years we should be seeing all sorts of new 
technology on the market that'll only serve to drive down prices. Besides, 
with fuel prices being what they are these days, the cost of the 
electricity needed is likely less than that of gasoline (though I don't 
feel like searching for figures at the moment). Charging stations already 
existing in parking lots and parking decks that electric car owners can 
plug their cars into while they're parked (my 'local' mall has two such 
spaces and I live in the middle of nowhere, hence the 'local', so I imagine 
they are more prevalent in more populous areas). They will only become more 
prevalent as electric cars become more prevalent and while not wireless 
right now, the technology exists and is efficient enough that there's no 
reason to assume we won't be seeing a shift in that direction in the next 
decade (I mean, hell, it's not even theoretical- wireless charging stations 
are already out there. That's what +Hirsh Kabaria and I were referring to.)

I'm not intentionally trying to attack your every post or anything. I just 
think this has so many exciting ramifications and the technology exists to 
make this happen (and it is happening on a small scale). Yes, some of the 
things I've mentioned aren't all that practical yet, but they easily could 
be on the market within a decade. The only thing that'll keep that from 
happening is if this current iteration of the technology doesn't see more 
widespread adoption, which won't happen if everyone just assumes it's not 
practical and is prohibitively expensive (while shelling out 300-500USD for 
a new iphone every two years... sorry, that's another rant all together).

+finnmaura thats definitely not practical right know. Wirelessly chargeing

comments.author: owen west

comments.text:
+owen west Charging would be done in your garage with induction coils 
beneath the floor, while you sleep, and hey! off peak hours too (plus 
electric cars also charge their batteries from the braking force). Yes, you 
would still have to pay your own electric bill but it takes almost no 
electricity to maintain the field so you're kinda only paying when you're 
running a device and you do that anyway. You could easily power an iphone 
wirelessly, the problem is we suck at storing energy and batteries are not 
only super inefficient but they are thrown out by the billions each year 
just because they're easier than getting a cord and plugging something in. 
With manufacturing, shipping, packaging, distribution, etc. along with 
their inefficiency 1kw/hr from an iphone battery costs roughly $24. If you 
had it plugged into the wall 1 kw/hr would cost about $0.19. Sure it'll 
take awhile (honestly 10-15 yrs before houses start being built with 
magnetic induction coils in the floors, walls, and ceilings) but once your 
house and your office and the coffee place all have them installed (think 
wifi) then it will be like your devices are always plugged directly into 
the wall. We will use less electricity, it will be cheaper, and renewable 
energy sources will become a hell of a lot more practical.
